bioghist.p: British screenwriter and producer Philip Mackie was born in Salford, Lancashire on 26 November 1918. He studied English at University College London, graduating in 1939. After serving in the army in World War Two, he worked for the Ministry of Information, producing documentary films. From 1954 he began a career as a writer, publishing a novel, Hurrah, the Flag! (1957), in addition to scripting several works for theatre and the BBC. He served as Granada Television's Head of Drama from 1958-1962, and then worked primarily as a freelancer for the rest of his career. Many of his productions are adaptations of classic works (Maupassant [ITV, 1963], Raffles [Yorkshire TV, 1977]) or based on the lives of historical figures (The Caesars [ITV, 1968], Napoleon and Love [ITV, 1974]). His best-known work is probably The Naked Civil Servant (ITV, 1975), an adaptation of Quentin Crisp's autobiography. Mackie died on 23 December 1985.

scopecontent.p: This collection holds the papers of the writer Philip Mackie, including scripts, correspondence, and other documents from his writing career, as well as some personal papers. The collection covers Mackie's novels, stage plays, films, and television productions dating from the 1950s to the 1980s.

arrangement.p: The collection is securely kept in the library basement, and it is organised in box-files, arranged alphabetically by title of the work contained within them.

appraisal.p: All of the contents in the archive are to be retained permanently.

accruals.p: This was a one-off donation; further accruals are NOT expected.

processinfo.p: The biographical information was gathered from an obituary in The Times (27 December 1985) and the BFI's ScreenOnline (both of which were last accessed on 6 December 2022).

custodhist.p: The collection was donated by Barbara Mackie in 2006.

bioghist.p: Philip Mackie (born Salford, Lancashire, on 26 November 1918 and died Swindon, Wiltshire, on 23 December 1985) was a British film and television screenwriter. His works include The Caesers, Raffles, Mr Rose, The Naked Civil Servant and more. The Philip Mackie Collection was donated to Solent University and comprises scripts, notes, personal letters and diaries (often with annotations by hand).

scopecontent.p: Papers that relate to literary output of Philip Mackie. The majority of items are typewritten scripts used in the production of TV programmes or films, but also included are notes and letters relating to these works and to his play and novel.

arrangement.p: The literary papers are loose and unbound screenplays organised in boxes.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous Articles, Notes, and Professional Papers

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous articles, notes, and professional papers by Philip Mackie.

Detailed contents:
A copy of Monthly Review , published by the Central Office of Information: Films Division, from August 1947, containing Mackie's article Production History of a C.O.I. Film .
Television plays: subject and treatment , which appears to be workshop material prepared by Philip Mackie for TV Writers School. It contains a brief biography of Mackie, a discussion of the nature of TV writing, and practical exercises. It is accompanied by a letter from the TV Writers School (dated 22 June 1960) asking Mackie to produce lesson material, and by similar material, already used by the school, written by Arthur Swinson.
An untitled critique of The Man with the Movie Camera , a Ukrainian silent documentary film, directed by Dziga Vertov, 1929.
Notes on the supernatural, taken from books including Strange Powers and The Occult by Colin Wilson.
An arbitration by Mackie, on behalf of the Writers' Guild of Great Britain, of a dispute about screen-writing credits for the 1976 film Crime and Passion , whose earlier title was An Ace Up My Sleeve .
An article for the TV Times, written December 1980, introducing his series Cover .

arrangement.p: Held in boxes 126, 128, 149, and an unnumbered box labelled Finances 76.

corpname.emph: British Screen and Television Writers Association

scopecontent.p: Papers relating to various ideas for films, novels, etc. by Mackie.

Contents include:
-- Outline and Synopses for a film, As Good as a Feast , by Philp Mackie and J. C. Sheers.
Story Outline for The Missing Aunt , by John Brabourne.
-- Synopsis for a film about Dr. Barnado, sent by Mackie with covering letter to Ursula Winant. [There are also notes on Barnardo in a notebook in box 143.]
-- Suggestions for the format of Alec Guiness Theatre , apparently a proposed series of teleplays, drafted by Mackie in 1957.
-- Typewritten notes from a writing course held in 1957 by the British Screen & Television Writers Association. The notes appear to have been distributed at the course.
-- Four typewritten pages of suggestions for potential US TV shows drafted by Mackie in 1952.
-- Typewritten draft treatments for a feature film entitled Fog , or Fog Warning by Mackie and John Haggarty.
-- Outline of a story called The Brain , by Mackie.
-- Notes by Mackie for an updated and anglicized version of the French Robert Macaire stories.
-- Notes and draft script for a play titled variously, The Room or The Guilty .
-- Typewritten script for The Fisherman's Wife , by Mackie based on a story by the brothers Grimm.
-- Synopsis of a film entitled Down River by Mackie.
-- Letter dated 11 July 1955 from Mackie to Benjamin Fisz of Golden Era films offering suggested improvements to the scrip and story of Hell Drivers , which was eventually produced by Fisz in 1957, apparently without incorporating Mackie's suggestions.
-- A treatment for a film version of John Wyndham's The Day of the Triffids prepared by Mackie and Alvin Rakoff, with a covering letter from Kaydor Productions returning the typescript.
-- Notes on the novel Jubb by Keith Waterhouse, evidently with a view to turning it into a drama of some sort, in a notebook. [In box 143].
-- Correspondence (1976) between Mackie and Taurus Film relating to a grand project dealing with the European Renaissance. [In box 126].
-- Correspondence (1979) between Mackie and Hollandia Filmprodukties relating to a proposed TV series abut Han Van Meeregen, the Dutch painter and forger. Included is a treatment for the series by Samuel Meijering [In box 127]
-- Correspondence (1976-1982) between Mackie and Peter Hopkinson relating to a series about the English in Malaysia, variously titled Blood Count , Samarang , and The Eagle and the Dragon . Included are various synopses and treatments. [In boxes 126 - 128]
-- Correspondence and a synopsis for a teleplay called False Witness , which is intended as part of the Armchair Thriller series.
-- Correspondence relating to a potential teleplay about Diaghilev. [In box 127].
-- A letter from Michael Ashe (1982) detailing several 'notions', i.e., plot outlines, for the series Hourglass Thrillers that he was trying to put together. [In box 128]
-- A letter from Ian Warren (1981) discussing the possibility of Mackie working on a series to be called Butterfly Bay , or, The Last Resort . Included is a bible for the series by Rick Searle. [In box 128]
-- Letters from Colin Shindler (1984) about Mackie writing for a mini-series called Maximilian in Mexico . Included is a treatment for the series, written by Shindler. [In box 129].
-- Letter from Stephen Ujlaki, HBO, (1983) about Mackie writing for a series set in Palestine a few years after the death of Jesus, provisionally titled The Inquiry . Included is a synopsis of the series, dated February 1982. [In box 129]
-- Correspondence with Charles Bloch (1985) about Mackie writing a film version of the Vincent Cosgrove novel The Hemmingway Papers . Included are Mackie's notes on the project and a summary of the story from Bloch. [In box 130]

scopecontent.p: Papers relating to A Nest of Spiders , a proposed six part TV series by Mackie that appears never to have been produced.

Includes draft scripts for the first episode and storylines for the remaining five episodes. It appears to have been under consideration for production, possibly at the BBC, as there is a memo from Mackie to D.S.S. [Director of Series and Serials?] accompanying the drafts. There is also a brief and critical handwritten response from another member of staff.

did.unittitle: A Season of Giants, or, Michelangelo

scopecontent.p: Papers apparently relating to A Season of Giants , a 1990 US/Italian mini series about the life of Michelangelo. The series is titled Michelangelo in Mackie's outline and bible, which obviously must have been written in the very early stages of production, but Mackie is posthumously credited on the series according to the BFI's ScreenOnline database, so it seems likely that these items relate to the series.

Detailed contents:
Two copies of a bible for the series (181 pages each).
One copy of the outline for the various parts of the series.
Correspondence relating to the production, including with Stephen Smallwood, CP Films.
Papers relating to A Sight of Diamonds , a film about diamond smuggling that Mackie did some provisional work on, but which appears never to have been made.

Contents include an outline treatment for the film (34 pages), some handwritten notes, some typewritten notes based on articles about diamond smuggling in magazines, a four page treatment sent to a producer, named only as "John", in July 1956.
Papers relating to Across a Crowded Room , a teleplay written by Mackie that was broadcast on Yorkshire Television in 1978.

There is correspondence between Mackie and director Peter Duguid and Lloyd Shirley, Thames TV, in which they discuss revisions and casting. scopecontent.p: Personal papers of Philip Mackie, including diaries, financial papers, and newspaper cuttings related to his writing.

Various personal letters and correspondences of Philip Mackie. As well as correspondence with friends and family, it includes letters from the public and colleagues praising, occasionally criticising, his work, sometimes with Mackie's response. There are particularly large collections of these letters for The Caesars , East Lynne , and The Naked Civil Servant .
Includes correspondence with Quentin Crisp, twelve letters between 1975 and 1980, some with Mackie's response.

Other notable correspondents include:
Lois Garner (Mrs James Garner); Sam Rosenberg; Andre Morell; Lord Sidney Bernstein; Arnold Goldman.

note.p: Correspondence relating to the production of specific works (e.g., about re-writes, casting, shooting schedules etc.) is mentioned in the description of those works under Literary Papers .
Correspondence relating to contracts, payments, and other financial matters is mentioned under Finances .

scopecontent.p: Diaries for selected years between 1963 and 1985, an address book, and a passport used between 1947 and 1952. The diaries mainly record appointments and are sparsely filled. There is also a notebook containing (in addition to writing notes) a detailed record of Mackie's a one week stay at Grayshott Hall, a health spa in Surrey.

arrangement.p:
The diaries, address book, and passport are in two unnumbered boxes labelled "Diaries" at the end of the collection.
The notebook with details of the stay at Grayshott Hall is in box 43.

scopecontent.p: Certificates, statements, correspondence, and other documents relating to Mackie's finances: insurance, pensions, income, and bank accounts. In addition there is corresponence relating to the legal and financial side of the lease on Philip Mackie's London flat and the ownership of Siddington Old Rectory and its associated land, including correspondence with the Bathurst Estate about the boundaries of the respective properties.

arrangement.p: Held in boxes 2; 126-130; 131b; three unnumbered boxes labelled "Insurance, Pensions", "Finances 77-79" and "Finances 79-82".

scopecontent.p: Various press clippings relating to Philip Mackie's life and works, principally clippings of reviews concerning several of Mackie's works. There are two formal obituaries of Mackie and two posthumous articles about him, all pasted onto one sheet. There are also pamphlets and promotional materials relating to Mackie's works.
